title: Number of Subsets in a Set
content_html:
1. Introduction to Sets and Subsets

A set is a well-defined collection of distinct objects, called elements. For example:

  • A = \{1, 2, 3\} is a set with three elements.

A subset of a set is any set whose elements are all contained in the original set.

For A = \{1, 2, 3\}, the following are subsets:

  • \emptyset (the empty set)
  • \{1\}, \{2, 3\}
  • \{1, 2, 3\} (the set itself)

By definition:

  • The empty set is a subset of every set.
  • Every set is a subset of itself.

2. Determining the Number of Subsets

If a set contains n distinct elements, the total number of subsets is:

\( 2^n \)

Why? For each element, there are 2 choices: include it or exclude it.

Examples

  • If \( A = \{a, b\} \) (n = 2), number of subsets = \( 2^2 = 4 \)
  • If \( B = \{1, 2, 3, 4\} \) (n = 4), number of subsets = \( 2^4 = 16 \)

3. Proper Subsets

A proper subset is a subset that is not equal to the original set.

The number of proper subsets of a set with n elements is:

\( 2^n - 1 \)

Example: For \( A = \{x, y\} \), total subsets = 4, proper subsets = \( 4 - 1 = 3 \):
\( \emptyset, \{x\}, \{y\} \)
